div1.p: Truby writes of Lampson's novel on yellow fever. He believes that it distorts the truth and perpetuates false statements.

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, May 22, 1943
div1.opener:
will forward
Lampson's book soon
answered
5/30/43
Albert E. Truby
145 Laurel Street
San Francisco, California
May 22/43
Dear Col. Hench:
div1.p:
Thanks for the photos. I won't need
any more of them except the one of Mrs T.
& me with my masterpiece in wood working.
I would like a couple more of that one.

I have no relatives by the name
of Trubey and certainly no nephews
by that or any other name. I do
have a few relatives by the name
of Truby. There are Trubys in Ohio
and Pennsylvania but they are not
relatives of mine. Our tribe is all
centered in and near Buffalo, N.Y. I
wonder where Melvin F. Truby is from?
If you run across him please find
out for I have never heard of anyone
by with that name.

I have enjoyed Lampson's book. It
tells much that I know about and is,
therefore, very interesting. As to the “cadence”
I think it most tiresome. It is a
novel pure & simple but it is based
on a mass of facts. Unfortunately the,
facts are placed in the mouths of various
AC
T
characters in the story regardless as to who
uttered them originally. This distorts things
dreadfully and helps to perpetuate false
statements. He also adopts everything every
writer has tosaid without regard to the facts.
An example of this is the swearing & foul
language used by Sidney Howard in his
“Yellow Jack”. Our medical officers never
were guilty of that and even the language
of the enlisted men was never at the low
standard which Howard depicted.

I was astounded at the mass of reading
Lampson had to do to get all the stuff in
his story. He must have had all the old news-
papers of the Gorgas family as well as all
letters, reports etc which they had. How energetic
he must have been. Reminds me in that
respect of one Philip S. Hench, but unlike him
in that he publishes everything regardless
as to whether it is true or not. Of course
he labels it a novel and therefore, even if
it is in quotation marks, it at once loses
value for historical purposes. The average
reader can not separate the wheate from the chaff.

I have used a blue pencil in making
remarks in the book. I hope that I have
not disfigured it too much. When my book
comes out you can compare my version on
many points with those of the author. I hope
you will be able to locate him and get the
source of some of his info.

My daughter & her little family will be here on
the 28th. So we are all agog. Her husband is
the grandson of the Late Col. Lauis a La Gorde, who was
Chief Surgeon at Siboney, Cuba (see Lampson's book).
No news re my book, but should get info. soon.,
